metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Some American Medical Botanists, a work of biography published in 1911 by Howard A. Kelly, an American naturalist and physician.
main_question:
He went beyond Bear creek to the forks of the rivers and there saw it growing in great masses-acres, in fact, covered as thickly as clover fields. Wagon-loads were eventually taken away and still there appeared to be no diminution in abundance. So the search for Shortia ended. Through the further efforts of Mr. Harbison, the plant is now well known and a common one in nursery catalogues, [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]. grows at its finest and best under the shade of kalmias and rhodendrons."

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause acknowledging a countervailing fact]:
answer_strings: though in its wild state it
though when domesticated it
although it was hoped, in vain, that "revisiting the haunts of his youth and the pleasing recollections of juvenile scenes would have salu- tary influence in arresting the disease
though it is not always easy to find and propagate
though it remains scarce in its native habitats
passage: He went beyond Bear creek to the forks of the rivers and there saw it growing in great masses-acres, in fact, covered as thickly as clover fields. Wagon-loads were eventually taken away and still there appeared to be no diminution in abundance. So the search for Shortia ended. Through the further efforts of Mr. Harbison, the plant is now well known and a common one in nursery catalogues, though in its wild state it. grows at its finest and best under the shade of kalmias and rhodendrons."

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Some American Medical Botanists, a work of biography published in 1911 by Howard A. Kelly, an American naturalist and physician.
main_question:
I shall be pleased in your calling on your intended journey, and hope you will consider my uncle's house as a welcome stage. I am, with all due respect, Your much obliged friend, MOSES MARSHALL. Marshall's letters speak of many long trips which meant fatigue, danger and expense. His appointment as justice of the peace curtailed excursions, [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]. About 1797 he married Alice Pennock and had six children.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]:
answer_strings: but he continued exchanging specimens and seeds with European confrères
but he ceased trading specimens and seeds with European colleagues

however, to get him a wife, Miss Christie; then he returned to Pennsylvania and became a public character, holding in succession the offices of surveyor-general, master in chancery and lieutenant-governor
but always without success
but his family now provided him with new reasons to travel
though it curtailed his wanderings, it also bound him to the duties of his office
passage: I shall be pleased in your calling on your intended journey, and hope you will consider my uncle's house as a welcome stage. I am, with all due respect, Your much obliged friend, MOSES MARSHALL. Marshall's letters speak of many long trips which meant fatigue, danger and expense. His appointment as justice of the peace curtailed excursions, but he continued exchanging specimens and seeds with European confrères. About 1797 he married Alice Pennock and had six children.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Some American Medical Botanists, a work of biography published in 1911 by Howard A. Kelly, an American naturalist and physician.
main_question:
He studied medicine under Dr. Nicholas Way of Wilmington, but never held a medical degree, none being required at that time for practicing in Pennsylvania; but, as it was customary to attend a course of lectures, he went to those by Shippen and Rush in Philadelphia. His diary at this time shows that medicine did not wholly absorb his attention, [masked clause describing a cause or reason] Then followed a year or two employed in desultory medical work, including inoculations round about Londongrove, Pennsylvania, and in keeping an apothecary's shop "which came to nothing and less."

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
answer_strings: for frequent mention is made of a certain Polly Howell and a Sally Samson, the latter "behaving for three evenings, especially the last, in a most engaging manner."
for there is scarce any mention of anyone named Polly Howell or Sally Samson, neither being noteworthy

owing to the fact that the authorities were wise enough to adopt the stringent sanitary precautions urged by Bigelow, who, with Ware and Flint, offered his services as investigator of the conditions in New York
for the old man was at least enabled to distinguish his favorite plants as he walked in his gardens
as he was also deeply engaged with his studies of botany
because his interests lay more in the practical affairs of his community than in theoretical study
passage: He studied medicine under Dr. Nicholas Way of Wilmington, but never held a medical degree, none being required at that time for practicing in Pennsylvania; but, as it was customary to attend a course of lectures, he went to those by Shippen and Rush in Philadelphia. His diary at this time shows that medicine did not wholly absorb his attention, for frequent mention is made of a certain Polly Howell and a Sally Samson, the latter "behaving for three evenings, especially the last, in a most engaging manner." Then followed a year or two employed in desultory medical work, including inoculations round about Londongrove, Pennsylvania, and in keeping an apothecary's shop "which came to nothing and less."

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Some American Medical Botanists, a work of biography published in 1911 by Howard A. Kelly, an American naturalist and physician.
main_question:
He still clung to the idea that its natural habitat must be, as Michaux said, in les hautes montagnes de Caroline, arguing that the point on the Catawba where it had been found was an outlying haven to which it might have been washed. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
answer_strings: So with renewed energy it was searched for through the mountains, but always without success.
So he abandoned the notion that it could be found in the mountains, and searched instead in the swamps of Carolina.

So also was the scene of his first settled practice, Hopkinsville, then a wild, romantic district where he gathered patients and plants, soon getting into touch with scientific men everywhere by exchanging specimens.
This belief led him to continue his search for the plant in the mountainous regions of North Carolina.
He inferred that the specimen had been transported downstream from its true mountain home.
passage: He still clung to the idea that its natural habitat must be, as Michaux said, in les hautes montagnes de Caroline, arguing that the point on the Catawba where it had been found was an outlying haven to which it might have been washed. So with renewed energy it was searched for through the mountains, but always without success.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Some American Medical Botanists, a work of biography published in 1911 by Howard A. Kelly, an American naturalist and physician.
main_question:
Dr. John Tennant, an enthusiastic botanist of Virginia, swears against all disputants by Seneca snakeroot for pleurisy; the experimenter and botanist, Dr. Samuel Thomson, later uses Lobelia inflata in his "Thomsonian System" for nearly every evil, and creates endless opposition. [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast] Of the young British doctors who came over here, John Mitchell was the earliest.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast]:
answer_strings: But the search for remedies was keen in days when malaria and dysentery ravaged whole towns and paralyzed industry.
But the search for remedies was sluggish in days when malaria and dysentery ravaged whole towns and paralyzed industry.

But the work which brought Bigelow into closest contact with European savants and gave him honor in his own country was the elaborate series published under the title "American Medical Botany," which was noted for its finish and beauty and avoidance of technical terms.
There was sometimes, however, bloodless warfare in the botanical camp in disputation over the alleged medicinal merits of certain plants.
While Dr. Mitchell's methods were more scientific and analytical, Dr. Thomson relied heavily on his own intuition and observations.
Tennant’s cautious endorsement of Seneca snakeroot clashed sharply with Thomson’s zealous promotion of Lobelia inflata, igniting a heated rivalry that reverberated through the medical community.
passage: Dr. John Tennant, an enthusiastic botanist of Virginia, swears against all disputants by Seneca snakeroot for pleurisy; the experimenter and botanist, Dr. Samuel Thomson, later uses Lobelia inflata in his "Thomsonian System" for nearly every evil, and creates endless opposition. But the search for remedies was keen in days when malaria and dysentery ravaged whole towns and paralyzed industry. Of the young British doctors who came over here, John Mitchell was the earliest.
